stem: PERSISTENT vs DEEP PERSISTENT — Load Reactivity Scenario: After 10 days with no avalanche activity and quiet, cold weather, a storm brings 20 cm of new snow with moderate wind. During the storm a large natural avalanche releases. Question: How surprised would you be that this event occurred when the only avalanche problem in the forecast was…
explain: Expected Key: Persistent Slab = moderately expected; Deep Persistent Slab = far less expected from modest loading.

stem: PERSISTENT vs DEEP PERSISTENT — Remote Trigger + Depth Scenario: A skier on a low-angle bench remotely triggers a large avalanche on an adjacent slope. The crown is 150 cm deep and the fracture propagates widely across connected terrain. Question: How surprised would you be that this event occurred when the only avalanche problem in the forecast was…
explain: Expected Key: Persistent Slab = very surprising (rare to remote-trigger a 150 cm crown); Deep Persistent Slab = not very surprising (classic DPS behavior).

stem: STORM SLAB vs WIND SLAB — Co-Occurrence Recognition Scenario: After a storm with 25 cm new snow and moderate wind, small human-triggered avalanches occur on lee wind-loaded slope with lens-shaped slabs. Question: How surprised would you be that this pattern occurred when the only avalanche problem in the bulletin was…
explain: Expected Key: Both = not surprised; storm and wind slabs commonly co-occur even if only one is listed.

stem: RISK MITIGATION — PS vs DPS Scenario: A group skis a steep open alpine slope with a deep (>200 cm) uniform snowpack above a large terrain trap. Their justification: "It hasn't avalanched in weeks and the snowpack seems strong. We'll just spread out and ski one at a time." A large destructive natural avalanche later releases on similar terrain. Question: How surprised would you be that this terrain choice resulted in a destructive avalanche when the avalanche problem was…
explain: Expected Key: Persistent Slab = moderately surprised; Deep Persistent Slab = not surprised (high-consequence DPS terrain).

stem: WARNING SIGNS — PS vs DPS Scenario: You observe no cracking, no whumpfs, no recent avalanches, clear visibility, and a generally right-side-up snowpack. Late afternoon: a large destructive natural avalanche releases nearby with no visible trigger. Question: How surprised would you be that this event occurred when the avalanche problem was…
explain: Expected Key: Persistent Slab = somewhat surprised; Deep Persistent Slab = not surprised (DPS often shows no surface clues).
